facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 243 to 246 of 1970 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 243 to 246 of 1970. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is

facts.text: Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 impugned as unconstitutional and void in these petitions

anchor.surface_text: The Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is impugned in these petitions as unconstitutional and void.

facts.text: Notices issued to petitioners under section 6 of Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 to evict from Government land

anchor.surface_text: Notices have been issued to the petitioners under section 6 of that Act in order to evict them from a certain piece of land claimed to be Government land.

facts.text: Challenge to constitutional validity of Act based solely on Northern India Caterers v. Punjab 1967 3 SCR 399

anchor.surface_text: The challenge to the constitutional validity of the Act is based solely on the decision of this Court in Northern India Caterers v. Punjab  1967 3 SCR 399 .

facts.text: In Northern India Caterers case, State leased premises to appellant for running a hotel

anchor.surface_text: In that case the validity of the Punjab Public Premises and Land  Eviction and Rent Recovery  Act, 1959 was under consideration. The State had leased its premises to the appellant therein for running a hotel

facts.text: In Northern India Caterers case, lease expired and appellant called to hand over vacant possession but failed

anchor.surface_text: and when the lease expired called upon him to hand over vacant possession of the premises. On the appellant failing to do so the Collector issued a notice under S. 4 of the Punjab Act

facts.text: Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 provides measures for checking unauthorized occupation of Government lands

anchor.surface_text: The Tamil Nadu Act is entitled an Act to provide measures for checking unauthorized occupation of lands which are the property of Government.

facts.text: Section 2 of Tamil Nadu Act defines property of Government including public roads, watercourses, lands except specified exclusions

anchor.surface_text: Section 2 of the Act defines the property of Government as 2.  1  All public roads, streets, lanes and paths, the bridges, ditches, dikes and fences, on or beside the same, the bed of the sea and of harbours and creeks below high water mark, and of rivers, streams, nalas, lakes and tanks and all backwaters, canals and water courses, and all standing and flowing water, and all lands, wherever situated, save in so far as the same are the property-  a of any zamindar, poligar, mittadar, jagirdar, shrotriemdar or inamdar or any person claiming through or holding under any of them, or  b of any person paying shist, kattubadi, jodi, poruppu or quit-rent to any of the aforesaid persons, or  c of any person holding under ryotwari tenure, including that of a janmi in the Gudalur taluk of the Nilgiri district and in the transferred territory or in any way subject to the payment of land-revenue direct to Government, or  d of any other registered holder of land in proprietary right, or  e of any other person holding land under grant from the Government otherwise than by way of licence, and, as to lands, save also in so far as they are temple site or owned as house-site or backyard.

facts.text: Section 3 of Tamil Nadu Act: unauthorized occupier liable to pay full assessment on the land

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 lays down that any person who shall unauthorizedly occupy any land which is the property of Government shall be liable to pay the full assessment on the land.

facts.text: Section 5 of Tamil Nadu Act provides for penalty payment by unauthorized occupier

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 provides for further payment by such a person of penalty. Section 6 provides for eviction of such a person

facts.text: Section 6 of Tamil Nadu Act provides for eviction, forfeiture of crops, buildings on Government land

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 provides for eviction of such a person and for forfeiture of any, crop car other product raised on the land and any building or other construction erected on the land. Such eviction is to be carried out by serving a notice as provided under section 7 after giving him a reasonable time to vacate.

facts.text: Tamil Nadu Act has provision for summary inquiry if resistance to eviction, appeal to Collector order, revision by Government

anchor.surface_text: If there is any resistance to eviction the Collector or other officer ordering eviction is to hold a summary inquiry into the question whether the resistance was without any just cause. There is a provision for appeal against the order of the Collector or other officer and there is also a provision for revision by the Government.

facts.text: Section 14 of Tamil Nadu Act provides right of suit for aggrieved person

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 provides for a right of suit by any person deeming himself aggrieved by any proceeding under the Act.

facts.text: This Court pronounced decision in Maganlal Chhagganlal P Ltd. etc. v. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay on 11 April 1974

anchor.surface_text: In its recent decision in Maganlal Chhagganlal  P  Ltd. etc. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay Ors. etc.  1  pronounced on 11 April, 1974,

facts.text: Petitioners contended they were still in possession

anchor.surface_text: In the result the writ petitions are dismissed. We must, however, mention that on behalf of the petitioners it was contended that they were still in possession.

facts.text: State contended that three of the petitioners had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, on behalf of the State it was contended that, three of the petitioners. had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay.

facts.text: Writ petitions dismissed

anchor.surface_text: This decision would apply on all fours to the facts of the present case, In the result the writ petitions are dismissed.

facts.text: Counsel for petitioners: Jayaram and R. Chandrasekhar

anchor.surface_text: Jayaram and R. Chandrasekhar, for the petitioner. Govind Swaminathan, A. V. Rangam, N. S. Sivan and A. Subhashini, for the respondents.

facts.text: Counsel for respondents: Govind Swaminathan, A. V. Rangam, N. S. Sivan and A. Subhashini

anchor.surface_text: Govind Swaminathan, A. V. Rangam, N. S. Sivan and A. Subhashini, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

facts.text: All public roads and streets vested in local authority deemed property of Government for purpose of Tamil Nadu Act

anchor.surface_text: 3 3 5 are and are hereby declared to be the property of Government except as may be otherwise provided by any law for the time being in force, subject always to all rights of way and other public rights and to the natural and easement rights of other land-owners, and to all customary rights legally subsisting. All public roads and streets vested in any, local authority shall, for the purpose of this Act, be deemed to be the property of Government.
Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is impugned in these petitions as unconstitutional and void.

issues.text: Whether the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is unconstitutional and void

anchor.surface_text: The Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is impugned in these petitions as unconstitutional and void.

issues.text: Whether the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 violates Article 14 by conferring an additional remedy over the remedy by way of suit and leaving it to the unguided discretion of the authorities

anchor.surface_text: In that case the validity of the Punjab Public Premises and Land Eviction and Rent Recovery Act, 1959 was under consideration. The State had leased its premises to the appellant therein for running a hotel and when the lease expired called upon him to hand over vacant possession of the premises. On the appellant failing to do so the Collector issued a notice under S. 4 of the Punjab Act requiring the appellant to show cause why an order of eviction should not be passed under s. 5. This Court while holding that there is an intelligible differentia between occupiers and that the classification has a reasonable relation to the object of the Act and does not offend Art. 14 also held that s. 5 of the Act confers an additional remedy over and above the remedy by way of suit and thereby violates Art. 14 by providing two alternative remedies to the Government and in leaving it to the unguided discretion of the Collector to resort to one or the other and to pick and choose some of those in occupation of public properties and premises for the application of the more drastic procedure under s. 5.

issues.text: Whether the procedure under the Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 provides sufficient guidelines, safeguards and is not unconscionably harsher than ordinary procedure so as not to violate Article 14

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 provides for eviction of such a person and for forfeiture of any, crop or other product raised on the land and any building or other construction erected on the land. Such eviction is to be carried out by serving a notice as provided under section 7 after giving him a reasonable time to vacate. If there is any resistance to eviction the Collector or other officer ordering eviction is to hold a summary inquiry into the question whether the resistance was without any just cause. There is a provision for appeal against the order of the Collector or other officer and there is also a provision for revision by the Government. Section 14 provides for a right of suit by any person deeming himself aggrieved by any proceeding under the Act.

issues.text: Whether the availability of two procedures (ordinary suit and special procedure under the Act) without guidelines violates Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It was argued before this Court that as there were two procedures available to the Corporation and the State Government, one by way of a suit under the ordinary law and the other under either of the two Acts, which was harsher and more onerous than the procedure under the ordinary law, the latter is hit by Article 14 of the Constitution in the absence of any guidelines as to which procedure may be adopted.

arguments.claim: The Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act, 1905 is unconstitutional and void under Article 14 as the challenge is based solely on Northern India Caterers v. Punjab where similar provision was held invalid for providing two alternative remedies without guidance

anchor.surface_text: The challenge to the constitutional validity of the Act is based solely on the decision of this Court in Northern India Caterers v. Punjab  1967 3 SCR 399 . In that case the validity of the Punjab Public Premises and Land  Eviction and Rent Recovery  Act, 1959 was under consideration. The State had leased its premises to the appellant therein for running a hotel

court_response_anchor.surface_text: al Judge of the City Civil Court in the city of Bombay, or to a District Judge in the districts who hag got to deal with the matter as expeditiously a

arguments.court_reasoning: Maganlal decision disagreed with Northern majority and applies on all fours here as object provides guidance and safeguards adequate

arguments.claim: In Northern India Caterers, unauthorised occupant not denied equal protection merely because Government has option of suit or under Act

anchor.surface_text: Two of the learned Judges who constituted the Bench, Hidayatullah and Bachawat, JJ. however held that the unauthorised occupant is not denied equal protection of the laws merely because the Government has the option of proceeding against him either by way of a suit or under the Act.

arguments.claim: The Act provides sufficient safeguards like notice under s.7, reasonable time to vacate, summary inquiry, appeal, revision, and suit under s.14 satisfying natural justice

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 provides for eviction of such a person and for forfeiture of any, crop car other product raised on the land and any building or other construction erected on the land. Such eviction is to be carried out by serving a notice as provided under section 7 after giving him a reasonable time to vacate.

arguments.claim: Statute's purpose of speedy eviction of unauthorized occupiers from Government land provides guidelines for using special procedure over ordinary suit

anchor.surface_text: The statute itself in the two classes of cases before us clearly lays down the purpose behind them, that is that premises belonging to the Corporation and the Government should be subject to speedy procedure in the matter of evicting unauthorized persons occupying them. This is a sufficient guidance for the authorities

arguments.claim: Special procedure under Act not unconscionably harsher than ordinary civil suit given safeguards, appeal to judicial officer, and Art.226/227 remedies

anchor.surface_text: Even though the officers deciding these questions would be administrative officers there is provision in these Acts for giving notice to the party affected... As against that there is only one appeal available in the other but it is also open to the aggrieved party to resort to the High Court under the provisions of Art. 226 and Art. 227 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Administrative officers will normally choose speedy special procedure and discrimination is improbable, not fanciful possibility

anchor.surface_text: Ever, normally one cannot imagine an officer having the choice of two procedures, one which enables him to get possession of the property quickly and the other which would be a prolonged one, to resort to the latter... It is not every fancied possibility of discrimination but the real risk of discrimination that we must take into account.

arguments.claim: Principles from Maganlal Chhagganlal v. Municipal Corporation apply on all fours upholding similar eviction Acts against Art.14 challenge

anchor.surface_text: In its recent decision in Maganlal Chhagganlal  P  Ltd. etc. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay Ors. etc.  1  pronounced on 11 April, 1974, this Court had, occasion to consider the constitutional validity of Chapter V-A of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act...

arguments.claim: Maganlal decision disagrees with majority in Northern India Caterers on two procedures issue

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, find ourselves unable to agree with the majority in the Northern India Caterers case.
We must, however, mention that on behalf of the petitioners it was contended that they were still in possession.

arguments.claim: Three of the petitioners had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, on behalf of the State it was contended that, three of the petitioners. had been evicted even before this Court passed an order of stay.

holdings.text: This decision would apply on all fours to the facts of the present case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principles from Maganlal upholding special eviction procedures against Art.14 challenge apply directly due to similar safeguards, guidance from statutory object, and improbability of discrimination

holdings.text: In the result the writ petitions are dismissed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenge to constitutional validity of Tamil Nadu Land Encroachment Act rejected following application of Maganlal principles distinguishing Northern India Caterers

holdings.text: We, therefore, find ourselves unable to agree with the majority in the Northern India Caterers case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory purpose of speedy eviction provides guidance; adequate safeguards including notice, inquiry, appeal, revision, suit; discrimination improbable as officers prefer speedy procedure

holdings.text: neither the provisions of Chapter V-A of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act nor the provisions of the Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act, 1955 are hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution
holdings.reasoning_summary: Quoted from Maganlal as analogous; special procedures not harsher unconscionably, with CPC powers, appeal to judicial officer, Art.226/227 remedies equivalent to second appeal

precedents.citation: Northern India Caterers v. Punjab  1967 3 SCR 399

anchor.surface_text: Northern India Caterers v. Punjab  1967 3 SCR 399

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 5 of the Punjab Public Premises and Land Eviction and Rent Recovery Act, 1959 confers an additional remedy over and above the remedy by way of suit and thereby violates Art. 14 by providing two alternative remedies to the Government and in leaving it to the unguided discretion of the Collector to resort to one or the other
precedents.cited_holding: s. 5 of the Act violates Art. 14

precedents.case_name: Maganlal Chhagganlal P Ltd. etc. Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay Ors. etc.
precedents.cited_proposition: Chapter V-A of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act and the Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act do not violate Art. 14 despite providing special speedy eviction procedure alongside ordinary suit procedure as there are sufficient guidelines, safeguards and the object provides guidance
precedents.cited_holding: neither the provisions of Chapter V-A of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act nor the provisions of the Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act, 1955 are hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution

precedents.cited_proposition: statute providing for a more drastic procedure different from the ordinary procedure covers the whole field covered by the ordinary procedure without any guidelines as to the class of cases in which either procedure is to be resorted to is hit by Art. 14

statute providing for a more drastic procedure different from the ordinary procedure covers the whole field covered by the ordinary procedure without any guidelines as to the class of cases in which either procedure is to be resorted to is hit by Art. 14; provision for appeal may cure the defect

in such cases if from the preamble the surrounding circumstances, as well as the provisions of the statute themselves explained and amplified by affidavits, necessary guidelines could be inferred the statute will not be hit by Art. 14

in such cases if from the preamble the surrounding circumstances, as well as the provisions of the statute themselves explained and amplified by affidavits, necessary guidelines could be inferred the statute will not be hit by Art. 14

where the statute itself covers only a class of cases the statute will not be bad; the fact that the executive will choose which cases are to be tried under the special procedure will not affect the validity of the statute

where the statute itself covers only a class of cases the statute will not be bad; the fact that the executive will choose which cases are to be tried under the special procedure will not affect the validity of the statute
